bioghist.p: Harris Wofford (b. 1926) is a politician, academic administrator and lawyer. After serving in the United States Air Force from 1944-1945, he received his AB from the University of Chicago in 1948. He received law degrees from both Yale and Howard Universities. From 1954-1958 he practiced law with the Washington firm of Covington and Burling. He taught law from 1959-1961 at Notre Dame Law School. From 1958-1959, he was counsel to Reverend Theodore Hesburgh on the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights. In 1959 Wofford joined Senator John Kennedy's pre-convention campaign and organized and coordinated the new Civil Rights Section of the presidential campaign. After the election, as Special Assistant to President Kennedy, he served on a new sub-cabinet Group on Civil Rights. He also sat on the task force which helped organize the Peace Corps and during the years 1964-1966 was Associate Director of the organization. He was a member of President Johnson's 1965 Smithsonian Task Force that prepared the President's proposals for the International Education Act. Wofford was President of the State University of New York's College at Old Westbury from 1966-1970 and then President of Bryn Mawr College from 1970 to 1978. After his tenure at Bryn Mawr, Wofford served as Pennsylvania's Secretary of Labor and Industry, where he established and led the Pennsylvania Office of Citizen Service. From 1991-1994 Wofford served as a United States Senator from Pennsylvania. After leaving office, he served as CEO of the Corporation of National Service.

scopecontent.p: The collection includes papers, books and videotapes. The bulk is devoted to Wofford's campaigns for election and his papers from his term as a U.S. Senator for Pennsylvania. A large collection of videotapes documents his second, unsuccessful campaign for election against Republican Rick Santorum. Additional material includes several book-length manuscripts, papers from his work as Pennsylvania Secretary of Labor and Industry, and various papers and manuscripts relating to his work in the fields of national service, civil rights, the Peace Corps, and African and international development. Wofford's political papers complement the papers from his tenure as President of Bryn Mawr College, also held by the Bryn Mawr College Library.
